articles.title: Global Famine Is Literally Inevitable As 77.6% Of The Earth Becomes More Arid And The Ground Beneath Our Feet Becomes More Unstable
articles.author: Michael Snyder
articles.summary: 77.6% of Earth's land has become drier in the last 30 years. If current trends continue, 5 billion people could live on drylands by the end of this century. Europe, Brazil, the western half of the U.S., the Mediterranean region, central Africa, and eastern Asia are most affected.

articles.title: Scientists debate best farming methods to reduce effects of climate change
articles.author: Sentient
articles.summary: NASA has announced that 2024 was the hottest year on record. Global warming is a serious problem in need of a serious solution. There is an ongoing debate among climate scientists about which solutions to prioritize and when. Food-related emissions are responsible for around a third of all greenhouse gas emissions. Factory farming and deforestation are big reasons why.

articles.title: Dr. Rob Williams: The Age of Geoengineering & How Its Primary Objectives are Military
articles.author: Editor
articles.summary: Dr. Rob Williams of Our Geoengineering Age discusses weather modification and how its function is primarily part of the military domain. This was a special edition of Geopolitics & Empire made possible by The People's Reset, consider donating to The People’s Reset as a thank you.

articles.title: The stakes just got bigger
articles.author: Robert Harrington
articles.summary: January 2025 was the hottest January in recorded history. It was a whole 1.7°C above pre-industrial levels. This year's La Niña phenomenon was expected to be cooler, but the climate itself didn't get the memo. Donald Trump's administration has no official stance on global climate change. Bill Palmer is expanding Palmer Report's operations so they can lead the fight against Trump.

articles.title: Home to Malay descendants, Australia's Cocos Islands face evacuation as seas rise
articles.summary: The Cocos Islands are threatened by coastal erosion and rising sea levels driven by climate change. The government proposes to relocate residents in the next 10 to 50 years. Shire of Cocos Island chief executive Frank Mills is 'disappointed' with the proposal. He is considering legal action against the government.

articles.title: Boiling Spring Lakes Dam Project Timeline
articles.author: Bill Murray
articles.summary: After Hurricane Florence, work to restore Boiling Spring Lakes in Brunswick County, North Carolina, has been going on for the last four years. The long-term completion date is 2027 for the project, which has a price tag of more than $54 million. The Upper Lake Dam is the closest to being finished.

articles.title: Africa's largest lake that's shared by 3 countries and over 200 miles long
articles.author: Kris Boratyn
articles.summary: Lake Victoria has a surface area of 26,600 square miles and its shoreline stretches over 2,000 miles. It is home to around 1,000 islands, some of which are inhabited. Lake Victoria was first documented by British explorer John Hanning Speke in 1858 during his quest to find the source of the Nile River. The lake supports the largest freshwater fishery in the world, producing over one million tonnes of fish annually and employing around 200,000 people. It has undergone significant biodiversity changes, particularly with the introduction of Nile perch, which has driven many native species to extinction.

articles.title: Most nations miss deadline for plans to fight climate change. UN says take your time to do it right.
articles.summary: Brazil, the United Kingdom, and the United Arab Emirates are the only major emitters to submit 2035 targets. The Marshall Islands, Singapore, Ecuador, Saint Lucia, Andorra, New Zealand, Switzerland, and Uruguay produce less than 0.2 percent of the world's carbon dioxide. UN Climate Secretary Simon Stiell said more than 170 countries have told his office they are working on their national plans.

articles.title: Where will Trump's strategy lead: Energy security or global destruction?
articles.author: Merve Suna Özel Özcan
articles.summary: Donald Trump has reversed many green energy and climate crisis-related policies implemented by former President Joe Biden's administration. Global warming has reached a critical threshold and the year 2024 represents a turning point in the fight against climate change. The Kyoto Protocol, signed in 1997, set a target for developed countries to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions by at least 5% compared to 2008–2012 levels. The Paris Agreement was adopted in 2015.

articles.title: US wildfire data misused following devastating LA wildfires
articles.author: Manon JACOB
articles.summary: Acreage lost to wildfires in the United States fell sharply over a century, despite far more fires deliberately lit. The US Bureau of Land Management says the data prior to 1983 is not reliable and there are concerning signs of more intense fire seasons in the country.

articles.title: New Smyrna Beach considers changes to development regulations to combat flooding
articles.author: Molly Reed
articles.summary: The New Smyrna Beach city commission is set to hold a public hearing and vote on changes to its development regulations. The changes aim to address the flooding issues that have plagued the area in recent years. One thousand homes were flooded during Hurricane Ian in 2022, 30 homes flooded last year in Milton and the roads were submerged for weeks.

articles.title: Horn of Africa to receive over 4 mln USD to tackle hunger
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: The European Union has provided 4.13 million U.S. dollars to support a joint project to protect vulnerable communities in the Greater Horn of Africa from the impacts of climate extremes, conflict, and displacement. The project will support 450,000 vulnerable people in Ethiopia and Somalia for two years.

articles.title: Most of the world's big polluters just blew off a major climate deadline
articles.author: Chico Harlan
articles.summary: The deadline for submitting national-level climate plans for reducing greenhouse gas emissions was on Monday. Most countries missed the deadline, including major emitters such as China, India and the European Union. Right-wing political shifts in democracies are driving climate downward as a priority. The United States is the world's largest greenhouse gas polluter, but under President Donald Trump it has pulled out of the Paris agreement and left a leadership vacuum.

articles.title: Satellite data study pinpoints areas sinking and rising along California coast
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Tracking and predicting sea level rise involves more than measuring the height of our oceans: Land along the sea bed is also important in the study of sea-level rise. It's a matter of land and not of sea levels as such.

articles.title: Modern slavery and climate change: How extreme weather fuels forced labor and unwanted marriages
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Weather-induced disasters that are the result of climate change are becoming more common.    - Professor Michael Schumacher, University of Cambridge.  -   "Climate change is a human-caused phenomenon".      for the study.

articles.title: China Cook Islands New Zealand
articles.author: No. 차이나 리포트
articles.summary: Cook Islands PM Mark Brown is speaking at the COP29 U.N. Climate Summit in Baku, Azerbaijan, in November 2024. He is the Prime Minister of Cook Islands. He speaks during a plenary session at the summit.    pic.

articles.title: Warm winter last year led to $2.5M surplus in Sudbury's snow removal budget
articles.author: Darren MacDonald
articles.summary: Experts say northeastern Ontario's major cities had their warmest winter on record in 2024, and it was warmer than usual.       in some places it was as warm as in any other year since records began in the mid-20th century.

articles.title: These 5 Big Cities Will See Home Insurance Premiums Skyrocket by up to 300% by 2055
articles.author: Lara Walsh
articles.summary: 40% of the $2.8 trillion spent on natural disasters since 1980 have been in the Sun Belt States: Florida, Texas, and California. Miami, Florida, Jacksonville, Florida (322%), Tampa, Florida  (213%), New Orleans, Louisiana (196%), and Sacramento, California (137%) will see the highest insurance premium increases from 2025 to 2055. Realtor.com calculated that the recent California wildfires put more than $40 billion of real estate value at risk.

articles.title: Beating the heat
articles.author: The Standard
articles.summary: There is a heatwave in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Some families are spending most of the night right next to the water. Last month was the hottest on record, but climate scientists expect cooler La Nina conditions to quell the heat streak soon.

articles.title: For the love of birds: How you can get in on the annual count Feb. 14-17
articles.author: Crystal Graham
articles.summary: The Great Backyard Bird Count is taking place from February 14-17. The data helps scientists better understand global bird populations before one of their annual migrations. Virginia State Parks will also hold events to celebrate the annual bird count. On February 15, Bear Creek Lake state park will offer a guided hike program.

articles.title: Baby name expert reveals that you'll see in the next decade — including Pippit and Hawk
articles.author: SWNS
articles.summary: Sophie Kihm, 27, has predicted the top 100 fastest rising baby names for 2025 to 2035. She predicts more names with a link to heritage, such as 'Fia', 'Yuna', 'Pippit', 'Lark', 'Hawk', 'Chozen', 'Chosen', and 'Iceylnn' are on the rise.

articles.title: Record heat of last year unlikely to be a one-off, scientists warn
articles.author: Kevin O'Sullivan
articles.summary: Last year's record warmth is likely to be part of a long-term shift to average temperatures of above 1.5 degrees, according to a study by Dr Emanuele Bevacqua of Helmholtz Centre for Environmental Research in Germany and Dr Alex J Cannon of Environment and Climate Change Canada. Both studies were published in Nature Climate Change and indicate the key Paris temperature target set in 2015 to minimise climate disruption is probably to be breached in coming years.

articles.title: January Was America's Coldest Since 1988, But Also Was Planet's Record Warmest
articles.author: Jonathan Erdman
articles.summary: January 2025 in the contiguous U.S. was 0.89 degrees Fahrenheit colder than the 20th century January average. It was the coldest January in 37 years. January 2025 was the planet's warmest January, topping the record set just one year ago. Australia had its second hottest January in 115 years, and vast swaths of Atlantic, Indian, Pacific and Southern Oceans were record warm.

articles.title: Catherine Austin-Fitts/Climate change lie/Dr. Nass/Waste-Fraud-Abuse/Whitney Webb
articles.author: Karen Bracken
articles.summary: Ex-Top Official Catherine Austin-Fitts talks about the Trump Administration's Road to the Future. She talks about man made climate change scam to depopulate and control humanity. She is worried about the bird flu caper. She points to a USDA spreadsheet on 1188 farms that depopulated 100 million chickens, ducks and turkeys.

articles.title: January was coldest in U.S. since 1988 but globe was warmest ever
articles.author: Jesse Ferrell
articles.summary: The January average temperature in the United States was 29.23 degrees Fahrenheit. It was the coldest January since 1988. West Virginia and Alabama had their 12th- and 15th-coldest January in the last 130 years. Copernicus reports that the Earth had its warmest January on record.

articles.title: World may have entered era of 1.5C warming, scientists say
articles.author: ETX Studio
articles.summary: Last year's record-breaking temperatures could be a sign that the world is entering a new era above 1.5C of global warming. Europe's Copernicus monitor has said last month was the hottest January on record, surprising climate scientists who had expected cooler La Nina conditions to ease the warm-streak.

articles.title: David Karoly's Climate Crisis – Fewer Frost Mornings in Melbourne?
articles.author: Eric Worrall
articles.summary: Eric Worrall and David Karoly discuss the decline in frosty days and other weather-related changes that people around the world are noticing and describing as 'weird'. Global temperatures have risen by an average of 1.55C compared to pre-industrial levels, and 2024 was the hottest year on record. Eric lived in Melbourne as a kid in a cheap uninsulated wooden house with a small fireplace and an asbestos sheet outdoor toilet. Many people in Australia still live in low quality houses. One in four Aussies struggle to pay home heating bills.

articles.title: Fires and floods are eviscerating US communities, intensifying the housing crisis
articles.author: Tribune News Service
articles.summary: The US is freezing and La Nina usually eases warming. Earth just set another heat record anyway.    i.e. there is no need to worry about La Nina because the Earth is already warm.  I.E. it's already hot.

articles.title: US Backtrack on Trump Gaza Plan, January Heat Record, AI Summit in Paris
articles.summary: World News Wrap includes US Backtrack on Trump Gaza Plan, January Heat Record, AI Summit in Paris, and January's temperature record. It's February 6, 2025 at 9:00 PM GMT.   It is February 6th 2025, 9 p.m. ET.

articles.title: Waste workers hit out at 'Hitchcock' like scenes at council site as dive-bombing seagulls swarm the skies
articles.author: JOHN PAUL BRESLIN
articles.summary: Council staff at the Polmadie refuse and recycling centre in Glasgow are fed up with the number of seagulls at the facility. They have enlisted their union to call for action and raise awareness of the situation. The union sent one of its members to pose in a life-size gull costume and pose for photos in the guise of 'Steven Seagull' to draw attention to the issue.

articles.title: 6 Million in Somalia to Need Humanitarian Aid in 2025
articles.author: Israa Farhan
articles.summary: Somalia faces a worsening humanitarian crisis. 5.98 million people are expected to require humanitarian assistance in 2025. The UN has launched a $1.43 billion humanitarian response plan for the year. At least 4.4 million people in Somalia are already experiencing acute food insecurity, while 1.6 million children are at risk of severe malnutrition by July 2025.

articles.title: Is there any hope for Paris Agreement targets after 2024 record temperatures?
articles.author: Stuti Mishra
articles.summary: In 2024, temperatures rose above 1.5C for 12 consecutive months. This is the key target set by the 2015 Paris Agreement. It is confirmed by the World Meteorological Organisation that 2024 was the hottest year on record. Without rapid decarbonisation, it will be difficult to prevent the climate from remaining above this threshold.

articles.title: Belize: $77 Million Project Launched To Build Climate Resilience In Sugarcane Industry
articles.author: CARICOM
articles.summary: Caribbean Community Climate Change Centre (CCCC) and the Government of Belize officially launched the 'Building the Adaptive Capacity of Sugarcane Farmers in Northern Belize' project. The launch took place at Escuela Secundaria Técnica México (Secondary and Vocational School of Mexico) in Corozal. The BAC-SuF project is a first-time initiative for the CCCCC and aims to strengthen the resilience of the Belizean sugarcane industry in the face of climate change. It has secured US$38.8 million in funding, including a US$25 million grant from the Green Climate Fund (GC

articles.title: Year above 1.5C suggests world is reaching long term warming threshold – studies
articles.author: London Evening Standard
articles.summary: The Paris climate treaty commits to curbing warming to 1.5C above pre-industrial levels, but 2024 exceeded that for the first time, according to the UNFCCC. The treaty is due to be signed in Paris on November 11, 2015.

articles.title: Two new studies suggest Paris climate goal is dead. One scientist is going even further
articles.author: Laura Paddison
articles.summary: Two new studies warn the world is on track to breach the Paris climate agreement goal of limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. Last year was the first calendar year to breach this threshold. President Trump pulled the US out of the Paris agreement and others are considering the same.

articles.title: Belize Secures $77M for Sugar Industry Climate Resilience
articles.author: Benita Keme-Palacio
articles.summary: The Caribbean Community Climate Change Centre and the Government of Belize launched the Building the Adaptive Capacity of Sugarcane Farmers in Northern Belize (BAC-SuF) project. The initiative aims to safeguard the vital sugarcane sector from climate change impacts. The project is expected to benefit over 5,000 farmers and positively impact approximately 87,000 people within their communities.

articles.title: Year above 1.5C suggests world is reaching long term warming threshold
articles.author: Emily Beament
articles.summary: A year with temperatures more than 1.5C above pre-industrial levels means the world is likely reaching the key long-term warming threshold, studies suggest. Under the global Paris climate treaty secured in 2015, countries agreed to limit global warming to 'well below' 2C and to pursue efforts to curb temperature rises to 1:5C. A record hot 2024 saw temperatures over the year for the first time.

articles.title: Year above 1.5C suggests world is reaching long term warming threshold
articles.author: Emily Beament
articles.summary: The year at 1.5C means the world is in the 20-year period where the long term threshold will be exceeded, according to two studies published in the journal Nature Climate Change. It's possible that we have already crossed the threshold or even crossed it.

articles.title: Calgary's warmest temperature for the next week will be 10 degrees below seasonal
articles.author: Jodi Hughes
articles.summary: Another cold spell for Calgary and Alberta. Jodi Hughes has a look at the five-day forecast from the Sky Watch Weather Centre. It's cold in Calgary and it's very cold in Alberta. It is cold in the rest of the province.

articles.title: Australia mulls 'retreat' from Cocos Islands
articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.summary: The Cocos Islands are threatened by coastal erosion and rising sea levels driven by climate change. The government proposes to relocate residents in the next 10 to 50 years. Shire of Cocos Island chief executive Frank Mills is "disappointed" with the proposal. Many people have been living on the islands for generations.

articles.title: Another cold spell for Calgary and Alberta
articles.summary: Another cold spell for Calgary and Alberta. Jodi Hughes has a look at the five-day forecast from the Sky Watch Weather Centre. It's cold in Calgary and it's very cold in Alberta. It is cold in the rest of the province.

articles.title: Experts Warn: Warm Year 2024 Will Not Remain an Isolated Case
articles.author: Akt.
articles.summary: The year 2024 was the first since records began to be more than 1.5 degrees warmer than the pre-industrial average worldwide. Greenhouse gas emissions must be rapidly and drastically reduced to keep the Paris climate goals within reach, according to the Austrian-German expert team.

articles.title: This Cape Vincent dairy farm is adapting to climate change with the help of a federal program
articles.summary: Hester Chase moved her dairy farm from California to Cape Vincent, New York, in 2000. She has been adapting to climate change for close to 25 years. Last year, she joined a climate adaptation fellowship with the USDA's Northeast Climate Hub. The fellowship provides education and support to dairy farmers who want to prepare for climate change.

articles.title: Almost half of remote French island hit by wildfire: official
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Amsterdam Island in the Indian Ocean has been hit by a wildfire since mid-January. The island is part of France's French Southern and Antarctic Lands in the Southern Ocean. Scientists and military personnel evacuated by boat from Amsterdam Island to Reunion. A French naval surveillance frigate Floreal is being despatched to the island to examine the current situation.

articles.title: ACCT to explore art and climate change at COA March 7
articles.summary: A Climate to Thrive explores the role of artists in communicating the hopes, fears and realities of a future impacted by climate change. Local visual artists Jennifer Booher, Maisie Richards and Emma Mary Murray will be in conversation at the Center for Human Ecology at the College of the Atlantic on Mar. 7 at 6 p.m.

articles.title: Year 2024 NOAA Measured Sea level Rise Data Show Climate Alarmists CO2 Driven Sea Level Rise Acceleration Claims Have Spectacularly Failed
articles.author: Larry
articles.summary: NOAA has just released its year 2024 measured U.S. Station Sea Level Rise data outcomes. Alarmists' claims of high rates of accelerating sea level rise due to increasing man-made CO2 emissions have clearly failed. Global CO2 emission has increased from 20.85 billion metric tons in 1988 to 35.13 billion tons by year end 2023. Developed countries' emissions are lower than in 1988.

articles.title: EU-Funded Initiative Launched to Protect Greater Horn of Africa from Climate and Conflict Crises
articles.author: Nairobi
articles.summary: The Scaling Coordinated Multi-Hazard and Conflict-Sensitive Anticipatory Action in the Greater Horn of Africa project aims to mitigate the effects of forecasted climate shocks before they escalate into full-blown crises. The project will directly support 450,000 vulnerable individuals in Ethiopia and Somalia over the next two years. It is funded by a generous contribution of EUR 4 million from the Directorate-General for European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations.

articles.title: Did cuts to shipping emissions spur more global warming?
articles.author: Antoine GUY
articles.summary: There is a sudden drop in pollution from cargo vessels criss-crossing global shipping lanes. The main reason for global warming is the heat-trapping emissions from burning fossil fuels, which is the main cause of the climate change.   .

articles.title: Panama's Rising Seas Displace Hope Seeking Indigenous Islanders
articles.author: The Latin American Post Staff
articles.summary: The Panamanian government decided to relocate the Guna Indigenous people from their ancestral coral atolls near Panama's northern shoreline for the mainland. The relocation shows how climate change affects real communities and the struggle to keep traditions alive. The Guna people have lived on the Gardi Sugdub island for over a century. The island is at risk of being submerged by 2050 due to rising sea levels.

articles.title: 'Year 2024 NOAA Measured Sea level Rise Data Show Climate Alarmists CO2 Driven Sea Level Rise Acceleration Claims Have Spectacularly Failed', Guest essay by Larry Hamlin
articles.author: Stephen Heins
articles.summary: NOAA has just released its year 2024 Relative Sea Level Rise data for its U.S. Station. Global CO2 emissions have climbed from 20.85 billion metric tons to 35.13 billion tons from 1988 to 2023 driven exclusively by the developing nations. Global mean temperature will rise at about 0.6 degrees F per decade and sea level at about 2.5 inches per decade.

articles.title: Winter poverty: The EU countries that struggle the most to heat their homes
articles.author: Alessio Dell'Anna
articles.summary: 11% of people in the EU can't keep their houses warm enough. The most vulnerable social groups are single people with children and single women. Mediterranean nations are the hardest hit, with 42% in Cyprus, 34.5% in Greece and 34% in Spain. Couples with two children have the lowest rate of people with such problems.

articles.title: There's a new outbreak of bird flu in Australia. Here's what you need to know
articles.author: AOL
articles.summary: A new outbreak of H7N8 bird flu has been detected in Australia. It was confirmed at an egg farm in northern Victoria at the weekend. The detection comes only weeks after quarantine restrictions were imposed. These avian flus are normally present in the waterfowl population.

articles.title: The Anomaly is +1.75°C
articles.summary: 'Copernicus' monitors the Earth System for the European Union. In June 2023, the average global temperature was +1.5 degrees higher. In the last three months of 2024, it was always above -1.6 degrees. Two years ago, conventional scientific predictions put us at + 1.75°C in about 2040. Gwynne Dyer is an independent journalist.

articles.title: Study finds climate risks threaten apple production in Washington, Michigan, and New York
articles.summary: A study from Washington State University examines climate risks for apple production in the United States. Yakima County, with over 48,800 acres of apple orchards, showed adverse trends in five of the six climate-related metrics. The United States produces about 260 million bushels of apples annually. Climate-induced yield reductions could raise consumer costs.

articles.title: Pakistan's 70% rainfall deficit threatens food prices and agricultural exports
articles.summary: A severe lack of rainfall this winter is affecting Pakistan's agricultural sector. The country has received nearly 70% less rainfall than normal. The dry spell is affecting winter crops, fruits, and vegetables in Punjab and Sindh, the primary food-producing provinces. The agriculture sector employs 38% of Pakistan's workforce.

articles.title: Scots council workers under siege by ‘explosive' seagull invasion take bizarre action to scare them off
articles.author: Alice Walker
articles.summary: There are hundreds of seagulls at the Polmadie Recycling Centre depot in Glasgow's east end, which has been plagued by them for the last few weeks. Staff at the depot claim their working environment is a danger because of the amount of filth caused by the invading birds. MBM's Chris Mitchell dressed as a giant bird to scare off the pests. Viridor, who manage the depot, said they are working to resolve the problem.

articles.title: Why La Niña's cooling effect could not reduce January temperatures
articles.author: Alind Chauhan
articles.summary: Last month was the hottest January on record. Global average surface air temperature was 1.75 degrees Celsius above the pre-industrial level. January 2025 was the 18th month in the last 19 when the global average surface temperature breached the 1.5 degree Celsius threshold. Scientists had expected the arrival of the La Niña phase, which emerged in December 2024, would bring some relief from the heat, but it did not happen.

articles.title: Top Skeptic of Climate Fanatics Spotlights Studies That Torpedo 5 Decades of Liberal Panic
articles.author: The Western Journal
articles.summary: Bjorn Lomborg is one of the world's best-known skeptics of the 'climate change' movement. He is a visiting fellow at Stanford University's Hoover Institution and president of the Copenhagen Consensus Center in Massachusetts. In January he wrote a column in the New York Post about the studies that show how wrong the greenies are about climate change. The studies show that technological advances and human ingenuity are more than capable of handling the challenges of a changing climate.

articles.title: Map Shows Where House Prices Risk Falling Due to Climate Change
articles.author: Giulia Carbonaro
articles.summary: $1.47 trillion in home values could be wiped out over the next 30 years due to climate change-related risks, according to First Street's study. The increased frequency and severity of natural disasters in the U.S. is already impacting the housing market, especially in vulnerable states like California, Florida, and Louisiana. Texas, Florida and California have absorbed over 40 percent of the nation's $2.8 trillion in natural disaster costs since 1980. The Sun Belt states are expected to face net declines of 10 to 40 percent by 2055.

articles.title: How the war in Ukraine has made flying worse for the climate
articles.author: Viktoriia Ivannikova
articles.summary: Some long-haul flights between Europe and Asia are emitting 40% more CO₂ since the Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. Longer flights consume more fuel and increase the operating costs for airlines. The war in Ukraine closed the country's airspace and limited access to the airspace of the Russian Federation and Belarus. This amounts to the biggest closure of airspace since the cold war, spanning 18 million km². Airlines that previously flew in Russian or Ukrainian airspace on routes between Europe, Asia, North America and Asia, and North America, the Middle East and the Arctic are taking detours.

articles.title: Is the Climate Debate Anything But "Argument by Cliche?" John Robson Asks and Answers!
articles.author: Thomas J Shepstone
articles.summary: Dr. John Robson of the Climate Discussion Nexus questions the claims that 2024 will be the worst year for climate. Robson speaks truth to political correctness.      .   in this video.  i.e. he questions the incessant claims that it will be worst year ever.

articles.title: HEDA Tasks State Govts On Seasonal Climate Prediction
articles.author: Oyenike Oyeniyi
articles.summary: The Human and Environmental Development Agenda (HEDA Resource Centre) has urged state governments to utilise the 2025 Seasonal Climate Prediction (SCP) to enhance economic resilience and sustainability. The appeal follows NiMet's release of the 2025 SCP, offering crucial insights into weather patterns affecting agriculture, water resources, disaster management, health, defence, maritime, transport, and aviation.

articles.title: Australia mulls 'retreat' from rising sea on Cocos Islands
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: The Cocos Islands, a group of 27 small atolls 2,936 km west of Australia, are threatened by coastal erosion and rising sea levels driven by climate change. The government proposes to relocate residents in the next 10 to 50 years. Many of the 600 residents are descendants of Malay workers brought to the islands to work in the coconut plantations in the 1830s.

articles.title: Is global warming accelerating?
articles.summary: January 2025 was 0.09 degrees C warmer than January 2024, the previous hottest January. It was the 18th month of the last 19 that the world hit or passed the internationally agreed upon temperature record. This era is the warmest in about 120,000 years or since start of human civilization.

articles.title: South-East Europe Enhances Climate Adaptation Efforts through Strengthened Early Warning Systems
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: 2024 was the hottest year on record, both globally and in Europe. South-East Europe is intensifying investments in meteorological and hydrological services to bolster early warning systems and enhance climate preparedness. The region has recently experienced a series of extreme weather events, including flooding, landslides, and wildfires.

articles.title: Rubirizi residents turn to wetlands over severe drought
articles.summary: Rubirizi District is facing a severe drought worsened by climate change. Crops are failing and people like Elias Ruhangambire are turning to wetlands for survival. Environmental officials warn about the long-term harm of wetland destruction in the district.

articles.title: Lots of rain, still too little water
articles.author: Dana Malcolm
articles.summary: Jamaica recorded eight per cent above average annual rainfall in 2024. However, the distribution was uneven throughout the year, with the island being impacted by severe flooding and drought. In February 2025, the Government allocated $134 million for drought relief as seven parishes recorded below average rainfall at the start of the year.

articles.title: Climate Change Imperils Pensions. Here's How Some Investment Managers Protect Them.
articles.author: Siddhant Pusdekar
articles.summary: Sierra Club and Stand.earth have released a report on climate change and pension funds. Some pension funds are taking active steps to protect their customers' finances from climate change risks, but most are not. The direct cost of a climate-change-driven economic downturn could be catastrophic for people's long-term investments.

articles.title: Most Charleston County residents are 'socially vulnerable' to severe weather, Census Bureau reports
articles.author: Jonah Chester
articles.summary: Census Bureau estimates about 60 percent of Charleston County residents have at least one vulnerability to extreme weather and nearly a fifth have three or more. The data is based on the agency's 2023 Community Resilience Estimates. Charleston County's estimated share of socially vulnerable residents might seem high, but the area is more resilient than most of the country.

articles.title: Stronger storms, higher tides: Here's what the Rising Waters Lab is focusing on as SC heats up
articles.author: Jonah Chester
articles.summary: Charleston and the rest of the Lowcountry are facing down a rising ocean. Sea levels in the region are predicted to rise by roughly a foot by 2050. Charleston is adopting new infrastructure to adapt to rising seas and strengthening storms. Inland and riverine communities are susceptible to the effects of a warming world.

articles.title: Weekly Climate and Energy News Roundup #630
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: Last week TWTW began a series on whether Climate Science Is a Physical Science. This week Ken Haapala, President, Science and Environmental Policy Project (SEPP) presents an essay by AMO Physicist Howard Hayden on Radiative Forcing and Atoms and Molecules.

articles.title: Biderap Dry Season
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Kulin Seasonal Calendar describes the seasons according to the movement of the stars, changes in the local environment, species behaviour and weather patterns. January to February is Biderap Dry Season, an exciting time of year for butterflies and insects. Knox Biodiversity team recently spotted a large population of Common Brown butterflies at Lakewood Nature Reserve in Knoxfield.

articles.title: Global January heat wave breaks records, raising climate alarm
articles.summary: January 2025 was 1.75°C (3.15°F) warmer than the pre-industrial average, continuing a worrying trend of record-breaking temperatures seen in 2023 and 2024. Scientists say human-caused greenhouse gas emissions are fueling the planet's rapid warming. Every fraction of a degree in warming increases the intensity and frequency of extreme weather events.

articles.title: Australia mulls ‘managed retreat' from rising sea in Cocos Islands
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: The Cocos Islands are threatened by coastal erosion and rising sea levels driven by climate change. The government proposes to relocate residents in the next 10 to 50 years. Many of the 600 Cocos Island residents are descendants of Malay workers brought to the islands to work in the coconut plantations in the 1830s.

articles.title: Community meeting Feb. 27 on rising sea levels and community impacts
articles.author: Louise Cowan
articles.summary: Boothbay Region Climate Action Team (BRCAT) will give a presentation on king tides on Thursday, Feb. 27 from 6 to 7:30 p.m. at the Boothbay Region YMCA. There will be sandwiches, pizza, beverages and discussion.

articles.title: Trump declares 9 February ‘Gulf of America Day', renaming Gulf of Mexico
articles.author: IANS
articles.summary: Executive Order 14172, signed on 20 January 2025, mandated changes to the US Continental Shelf area. The secretary of the interior was instructed to rename the body of water bordered by Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and Florida and extending to the maritime boundary shared with Mexico and Cuba. President Trump declared 9 February 2025 the inaugural Gulf of America Day.

articles.title: Is global heating accelerating? Top climate scientists heatedly disagree
articles.author: Matthew Rozsa
articles.summary: Last year was the first year in which global average temperatures exceeded 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. January was already the hottest in recorded human history. Global warming has translated into unprecedented heat waves, wildfires, floods and extreme storms all over the world.

articles.title: QuickCheck: Do some birds intentionally start wildfires?
articles.author: Gisele Soo
articles.summary: Some birds intentionally start forest fires to hunt their prey. Black kite, Whistling kite and brown falcon are known to do this in Australia. There is no physical evidence to support this behaviour.    The theory is based on an Aboriginal knowledge.

articles.title: Addressing climate challenges through the pillars of climate governance
articles.author: 3news.com
articles.summary: Climate change poses a multifaceted risk that adversely impacts every aspect of human existence and poses danger to animals, forest reserves, the environment, and business operations. The world is saddled with emerging global megatrend issues: human security, socially responsible stewardship, and environmental and climate change. A climate governance framework primarily relies on diplomacy, standardized mechanisms, and response measures to navigate social systems. The overall objective is focused on the pillars of climate governance: mitigation, adaptation, finance, technology and innovation, equity and climate justice, and transparency and accountability.

articles.title: Australia plans ‘long-term managed retreat' from Cocos Islands
articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.summary: The Cocos Islands, a group of 27 small atolls lying 2,936 km (1,824 miles) west of Australia, are threatened by coastal erosion and rising sea levels driven by climate change. The federal government's proposal suggests that residents, water resources, power stations, roads and shops be relocated in the next 10 to 50 years.

articles.title: Arctic set to undergo irreversible damage as hopes of hitting the 1.5C Paris target fade
articles.author: bne Intelli News
articles.summary: The Arctic is set to undergo dramatic and irreversible changes in the coming years if global warming reaches 2.7°C above pre-industrial levels. The disappearance of sea ice and the melting of the permafrost in northeast Russia will lead to unpredictable results. Global weather patterns will be drastically altered. The tundra contains huge swathes of the world's boreal forests, accounting for only 15% of Earth's soil area but storing around one-third of world's soil organic carbon.

articles.title: Kerala on the brink of becoming India's heat capital, warns climate report
articles.summary: Kerala's annual average temperature has risen by 0.99 degrees Celsius over the past 124 years. The most alarming increase was recorded in April, with temperatures soaring by 1.85 degrees Celsius. 2024 has been identified as the hottest year in the state's recorded history. December 2024 marked the hottest winter in Kerala's history.

articles.title: Why was January 2025 the hottest in history?
articles.author: Anmol Sharma
articles.summary: January 2025 was the warmest January on record globally. The reason could be increase in greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, variable atmospheric conditions, reduction in aerosol pollution and lingering water vapour from the 2022 Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha'apai volcanic eruption.

articles.title: Spotlight: Greenpeace Photographers Behind Lens
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Christian Åslund has been working for Greenpeace for more than 25 years. He has been taking glacier comparison photos from Svalbard since 2002. The Arctic is warming twice as fast as the rest of the planet due to a phenomenon known as 'Arctic amplification'. This accelerated warming has global consequences.

articles.title: Secret weapon' deployed at Glasgow cleansing depot after seagull invasion
articles.author: Exclusive
articles.summary: GMB sent 'Steven Sea-gull' to the complex in Polmadie after hundreds of seagulls began congregating at the site. They say the flying menaces pose a real risk to workers' health and safety. Viridor, who manage the depot, are working to resolve the problem.

articles.title: Pakistan one of the most climate-affected countries due to climate change: PM
articles.summary: Pakistan is one of the most climate-affected countries due to climate change. PM owns the property of Associated Press Of Pakistan. He is concerned about the climate change in Pakistan and wants to do something about it. He wants to change the current political system.

articles.title: Andhra sees early rise in daytime temperature
articles.author: Express News Service
articles.summary: Andhra Pradesh is experiencing a gradual rise in temperatures, with daytime maximums reaching up to 37 degrees Celsius this week. Lower tropospheric north-easterly winds are prevailing over North Coastal Andhra Pradesh and Yanam, while easterly and south-eastern winds influence weather conditions over South Coastal and Rayalaseema. Maximum temperatures are expected to remain 2 to 4 degrees Celsius above normal.

articles.title: Japan weather bureau says no signs of El Nino, La Nina
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: Japan's weather bureau says there are no clear indications of El Nino or La Nina events. La Nina characteristics are becoming evident. There is a 60% likelihood of ordinary weather pattern continuing towards the summer, according to the weather bureau. El Niño is a warming of ocean surface temperatures in the eastern and central Pacific, while La Nina is colder-than-usual ocean temperatures.

articles.title: Trump renames Gulf of Mexico as 'Gulf of America'
articles.summary: The renamed Gulf covers the US Continental Shelf area bordered by Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida. It stretches to the seaward boundary with Mexico and Cuba. The renaming comes amid heightened tensions between Trump's administration and Mexico. Trump's executive order stresses that this area has been an "integral asset" to the United States.

articles.title: Weather Bureau Highlights La Nina Tendencies Amidst Uncertain Patterns
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Japan's meteorological agency reports absence of definitive indications pointing to the onset of either El Nino or La Nina events. However, some characteristics of La Nina are starting to show. There is a 60% chance that an ordinary weather pattern will maintain itself as summer approaches.

articles.title: Africa: WFP, FAO Warn of the Severity of the Climate Crisis and Food Insecurity
articles.author: Oritro Karim
articles.summary: Climate shocks have become more frequent and have devastated economies and agriculture systems, exacerbating widespread malnutrition and hunger. The Paris Agreement seeks to limit average global temperatures to 2°C, but it is impossible to achieve due to rising energy use and climate change. In 2023, climate-induced disasters drove roughly 72 million people into emergency levels of hunger in Latin America and the Caribbean.

articles.title: Probe mangrove tree deaths in Balik Pulau, says Penang consumer group
articles.author: Fmt Reporters
articles.summary: Mangrove trees in Kuala Sungai Pinang, Balik Pulau, Penang have died due to pollution from nearby shrimp farming ponds. The situation will affect the livelihoods of 500 coastal fishermen in the area if the authorities don't take action.

articles.title: A majority of Australians think the country's migrant intake is too high
articles.summary: 52.9% of Australians think the country's migrant intake is too high, but only 4.5% think it's about right. 57.6% oppose cutting international student numbers. Immigration is expected to be a major policy issue in Australia's general election, which must be held by May.

articles.title: PNG achieves milestone in maritime sovereignty
articles.author: postcourieronline
articles.summary: Papua New Guinea has submitted its geographical co-ordinates under UNCLOS. It reaffirms PNG's territorial boundaries and maritime zones. This development is significant as PNG celebrates its 50th year of independence. It is also significant as it marks almost five decades of sovereign governance. It will enhance national security and support sustainable fisheries management.

articles.title: What Danish people think about Trump's plans for Greenland
articles.summary: In Denmark, Danes are confused and bemused by President Trump's territorial threats about Greenland. WUWF Public Media is located at 11000 University Parkway Pensacola, Florida 32514, 850 474-2787, and on air at WUWF HD2 and HD3.

articles.title: What Danish people think about Trump's plans for Greenland
articles.summary: President Trump makes territorial threats about Greenland. Danes are confused and bemused by the president's statements.   on air on KANW-FM and on kanw-2 on radio stations.  on radio on NPR on air  on the internet.

articles.title: ‘Greed of capitalist structures has pushed planet to brink of disaster'
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: Prof. Asghar Dashti, Nasir Mansoor, Qazi Khizar, Riaz Abbasi, and Home-Based Women Workers Federation President Saira Feroz spoke at a seminar titled "Workers in Peril: How Capitalism Fuels Climate Catastrophe & Exploitation" organised by the National Trade Union Federation of Pakistan. Dr Dashti warned that scientific advancement had failed to address climate changes adequately and warned that Pakistan could face freshwater depletion by 2050. The seminar was moderated by the NTUF general secretary.

articles.title: And the award for Australia's best beach goes to ...
articles.author: Akash Arora
articles.summary: A 20-kilometre coastal strip in Tasmania's Bay of Fires region has been crowned Australia's best beach. Bondi and St Kilda might get a little salty because of the beach's salty water.    i.e. water from the beach.

articles.title: How do we promote greater collaboration between genders to accelerate climate action?
articles.author: The National
articles.summary: Women are disproportionately impacted by climate change. Their voices are often left out of climate decision-making. In the second episode of the Women in Climate podcast series, host Naomi Kerbel speaks to Kathy Baughman McLeod, chief executive of Climate Resilience for All and Rachel Kelly, Climate Editor at The National.

articles.title: Fry to apply pressure to Feds to 'safeguard' amid growing bushfire concerns
articles.author: Rachel Chamberlain
articles.summary: Ben Fry is calling on the federal government to strengthen Australia's firefighting capacity. There is an increasing bushfire risk in Australia due to the drought and increasing bushfires.      .   for more information, visit www.africa.gov.au.

articles.title: Climate change — why action is imperative now
articles.author: Yousaf Hussain
articles.summary: Pakistan is ranked as the fifth most vulnerable country to climate change. The average temperature in Pakistan has risen by 0.5°C between 1960 and today. The World Bank projects that the combined effects of climate change, environmental degradation, and air pollution could reduce Pakistan's GDP by 18-20% by 2050. Pakistan took significant steps to reinforce its commitment to global climate action at COP29. OICCI has been playing a key role in furthering Pakistan's climate agenda.

articles.title: Balancing the crop and water equation
articles.author: Khalid Saeed Wattoo
articles.summary: Pakistan's agriculture sector consumes nearly 90% of the nation's water. The area under rice cultivation surged by 41% from 2011-12 to 2023-24, while sugarcane acreage grew by 12%. The current cropping patterns are dominated by water-intensive crops. Pakistan is currently classified as water-scarce. Some urgent policy and strategic adjustments are needed.

articles.title: Birds of Ireland: Grey Heron
articles.author: Jim Wilson
articles.summary: Grey Herons are around 90-96cm long and have a wing-span of 150-173cm. They live in wetlands or estuaries. Their breeding plumage features long, thin feathers on their neck/breast and two long black feathers growing from the back of their head. Their beak changes colour from dull yellow-orange to bright pink.

articles.title: Combating Drought
articles.summary: The Punjab government's plan to counter drought in the Potohar region is a much-needed initiative. Pakistan's economy remains heavily reliant on agriculture. Water scarcity and rising temperatures are depleting yields and pushing farmers towards financial ruin. The government's strategy must extend beyond short-term relief. Efficient irrigation practices and research into climate-resilient crop varieties should be actively implemented on the ground.

articles.title: Scary times fuel our apocalyptic hunger
articles.summary: The odds of an asteroid collision with earth more than doubled last week, from 1% to 2%. The Last of Us franchise on the Sony PlayStation has clocked up more than US$1 billion in revenue and spawned an immensely popular streaming series. The Walking Dead series has been running for 12 years and is still popular.

articles.title: Scary times fuel our apocalyptic hunger
articles.author: John Hanscombe
articles.summary: The odds of an asteroid collision with earth more than doubled last week, from 1% to 2%. The Last of Us franchise on Sony PlayStation has made more than US$1 billion in revenue and spawned an immensely popular streaming series. The government has committed $8.6 million to remove venomous snakes from Sydney's backyard.

articles.title: A majority of Australians think the country's migrant intake is too high
articles.author: Famagusta Gazette
articles.summary: 52.9 percent of Australians think the country's migrant intake is too high, but oppose cutting international student numbers. The survey of more than 5,000 people was undertaken by researchers from the Australian National University (ANU) and found that 52.9% of Australians believe this.

articles.title: Australia mulls 'retreat' from rising sea on Cocos Islands
articles.author: Khaleejtimes
articles.summary: The Cocos Islands, a group of 27 small atolls 2,936 km west of Australia, are threatened by coastal erosion. The Australian government proposes to move hundreds of residents from their island homes within decades as sea levels rise. The proposal has sparked outrage among the inhabitants.

articles.title: Indigenous business works to divert tonnes of food waste from tip
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Australians waste 7 million tonnes of food every year at a cost of $36.6 billion to the economy. A Darwin enterprise is doing its bit to change that by producing more wasteable food in the area. It's called "Darwin's Waste Management Project".

articles.title: Year above 1.5C suggests world is reaching long term warming threshold
articles.author: AOL
articles.summary: One year above 1.5C over pre-industrial levels does not mean the long-term threshold, measured over multiple decades, has been breached, according to two studies published in the journal Nature Climate Change. The world is in the 20-year period where it is likely the goal has been exceeded.

articles.title: Horn of Africa to receive over 4 mln USD to tackle hunger
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: The European Union has provided 4.13 million U.S. dollars to support a joint project to protect vulnerable communities in the Greater Horn of Africa from the devastating impacts of climate extremes, conflict, and displacement. Increasingly frequent and intense climate extremes such as droughts and floods are compounding existing drivers of hunger.

articles.title: Map Shows Where House Prices Risk Falling Due to Climate Change
articles.author: Newsweek
articles.summary: Climate change could wipe out nearly $1.5 trillion in home values in the U.S. real estate market over the next 30 years, according to a new study by the University of California at Los Angeles. The study was published in the journal "The Journal of Climate Change".

articles.title: How the war in Ukraine has made flying worse for the climate
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: Long-haul flights emitting more CO₂ since Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. Airspace closures above conflict zones forcing airlines to seek alternative routes, which is responsible for the increase in CO⁂ emissions, according to the study by the author.

articles.title: USAid climate programmes aimed to curb migration. Now they're gone
articles.author: Straits Times
articles.summary: Storms, extreme heat and crop damage are all drivers that increase migration, according to the researchers.    -      for migration, they say, because of the weather, heat, crop damage and storms. For more information, go to: http://www.researchers.org/.

articles.title: Did cuts to shipping emissions spur more global warming?
articles.author: San Francisco Examiner
articles.summary: is making the world hotter because of a drop in pollution from cargo vessels criss-crossing global shipping lanes. The world is making it hotter because it's getting more polluted.  Â. Â    yah. Yah.

articles.title: A climate change signal in the Tropical Pacific: Research reveals models' blind spot
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Extreme weather is driving a growing death toll, exacting billions in damage and threatening food and water security. Some of the most sophisticated climate models are missing. Lamont's work is at the center of the debate in the climate science community and has sparked scientists worldwide to rethink their models.

articles.title: Two new studies suggest Paris climate goal is dead. One scientist is going even further
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Two new studies conclude that the planet is on track to breach the Paris climate agreement goal of restricting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. The studies say it's a given that the threshold will be breached. The US is experiencing frigid weather, but for the planet as a whole, heat records are being obliterated.

articles.title: Unraveling a paradox: Study explores why extreme cold events persist despite global warming
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: 2023 and 2024 are the warmest years on record. Extreme cold events are still affecting regions across China, Europe and North America. Climate change has reduced the intensity of extreme cold events, according to a recent study published in Npj Climate and Atmospheric Science.

articles.title: Is global warming accelerating?
articles.author: The Hindu
articles.summary: The world warmed to yet another monthly heat record in January, according to the European climate service Copernicus. The world warmed by 0.7 degrees Celsius in January this year compared to last year.    in December.  in January 2013. in 2013.

articles.title: Call to action emphasizes physics researchers' role in combating climate change
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: "Climate change is real" is a statement that spearheads a new call to act on climate change.    "It's time to act now".  "There's a need to take action now". "There is a need for action now."

articles.title: Engineers design new autonomous system to monitor Arctic's melting ice
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: The rapid melting and thinning of the Arctic ice has sparked serious concerns in the U.S. and around the world, especially in the Arctic region.    The Arctic ice is rapidly melting and thinnening, and there are serious concerns about its future.

articles.title: ‘Greed of capitalist structures has pushed planet to brink of disaster'
articles.author: The News International
articles.summary: Dr Asghar Dashti is the author of "Workers in Peril: How Capitalism Fuels Climate Catastrophe & Exploitation". He believes that the survival of life on Earth is tied to the dismantling of this exploitative system.

articles.title: Climate change weakening extreme cold events: study
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: A joint study by Chinese and U.S. researchers has found that human-induced climate change is reducing the severity of extreme cold events. The study was published in the journal npj Climate and Atmospheric Science. It was conducted by researchers from the Institute of Atmospheric Physics at IAP.

articles.title: NASA-Led Study Pinpoints Areas Sinking, Rising Along California Coast
articles.author: NASA
articles.summary: Elevation changes can increase or decrease local flood risk, wave exposure, and local flood. NASA's home page is the source of this information.      .   "Elevations change by fractions of inches per year".   i

articles.title: Australia, PH vow to fight climate woes, reinforce disaster resilience
articles.author: Manila Standard
articles.summary: Australia and the Philippines agreed to strengthen efforts to mobilize funds, speed up climate change actions and reduce disaster risks. Australia is working hand-in-hand with Philippine national and local governments to develop strategies and drive actions that build lasting resilience to reduce the impacts of disasters and climate change.

articles.title: La Niña's impact on global warming may be waning
articles.author: The Jakarta Post
articles.summary: J anuary 2025 was the hottest on record, reaching a whole 1.7 degrees above pre-industrial levels. January 2025's record heat highlights how climate change is affecting the world's weather system. The natural La Niña phenomenon did not cool the climate this year.

articles.title: Most countries miss UN climate plan deadline as fears over Trump effect on global diplomacy grow
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: Most of the world's nations have missed a UN deadline to set new climate targets. Efforts to curb global warming come under pressure following U.S. President Donald Trump's election and his policies on climate change. The UN has set a new deadline for setting new targets.

articles.title: Scientists discover heat-resistant strain of sugar kelp
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Warming ocean temperatures have led to shorter growing and harvesting seasons for sugar kelp, one of the most commonly farmed kelp species. The loss of kelp populations can significantly impact ecosystems and potentially the growing. Some kelp may already have useful adaptations to cope with warmer temperatures.

articles.title: Fossil of oldest known modern bird unearthed in Antarctica
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: A fossil found in Antarctica is the oldest known modern bird. It is estimated to be 68 million years old and belongs to Vegavis iaai, an extinct bird species that lived during the late Pleistocene period. It was about the size of a mallard duck.

articles.title: World's biggest polluter nations miss UN deadline for new climate targets
articles.author: The News International
articles.summary: Global warming has reached 1.5 degrees Celsius for an entire year. Many of the world's biggest polluter nations have missed a UN deadline to set new climate targets as efforts to curb global warming have so far had little impact on the public.

articles.title: World may have entered era of 1.5C warming, scientists say
articles.author: CTV
articles.summary: last year's record-breaking temperatures could be a sign that it will be warmer this year.   for the next few months.  for next few weeks.  For the next several months    in the future   and  in this year and in the year.

articles.title: Record heat of last year unlikely to be a one-off, scientists warn
articles.author: The Irish Times
articles.summary: Last year's record warmth is likely to be part of a long-term shift to average temperatures of above 1.5 degrees, according to a major international study published on Monday. In a separate but related study scientists suggest the 12 months at 1. 5 degrees'signals earlier than expected'

articles.title: Climate change — why action is imperative now
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Pakistan is ranked as the fifth most vulnerable country to climate change. Pakistan contributes just 0.88 per cent of global greenhouse gas emissions. The far-reaching effects of climate change are directly impacting millions of lives in Pakistan and the rest of the world.

articles.title: Thriving through climate change
articles.author: Joseph Prosper
articles.summary: Deforestation for charcoal and firewood is a major cause of climate change in Tanzania. Deforestation is a crime against the state. Tanzania has 48.1 million hectares of forests and woodlands, 55 percent of the total land area. In 2022, the Vice President's Office, Environment, and Union Ministry initiated a campaign requiring every district council to plant 1.5 million trees.
